Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Economic Effects of Refugee Resettlement

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research supported by this award asks: how are agrarian regions that border conflict-ridden countries affected by forced migration? Social scientists increasingly recognize that displacement is often long-term. Therefore, policy makers must pursue alternatives to temporary refugee camps. But to do this effectively, policy makers need more information about how displaced populations affect the economic and social conditions of the regions where they settle. Long-distance migrations to Europe have garnered recent headlines, but refugees more typically flee to nearby countries, often to regions where they or their kin have previous social relationships. As governments negotiate the distribution of responsibility for hosting these displaced populations, finding sustainable and security-appropriate solutions to today's worldwide migration crisis has become a matter of concern everywhere, including in the United States.

The research will be conducted by City University of New York Graduate Center anthropology doctoral candidate, China Sajadian, advised by Dr. Mandana Limbert. Sajadian will undertake 12 months of research in Lebanon because Lebanon hosts the highest number of refugees per capita in the world. Over one-quarter of Lebanon's population is comprised of displaced Syrians, which makes the effects of forced migration there appropriately visible for targeted data collection and analysis. Sajadian will collect data with two primary methods. To document everyday labor practices and the specific effects of refugee settlement, she will conduct ethnographic research, including observation and interviews, among a stratified sample of 250 farmworkers in villages adjacent to the Syrian-Lebanese border. She also will pursue archival research about the history of land tenure, labor, and migration in the region. Findings from this research will inform policy makers about how loss of cross-border mobility for seasonal farmworkers reconfigures social and economic relations in the country of settlement. Knowledge of these processes will help policy makers develop approaches for dealing with refugees that are attentive to the specific predicaments, livelihood needs, and security challenges of borderland regions. Findings from the research also will be disseminated through academic publications and conference presentations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

The research supported by this award asks: how are agrarian regions that border conflict-ridden countries affected by forced migration? As governments negotiate the distribution of responsibility for hosting displaced populations, finding sustainable solutions to today's worldwide migration crisis has become a matter of concern everywhere, including in the United States. Long-distance migrations to Europe have garnered recent headlines, but refugees more typically flee to nearby countries, often to regions where they or their kin have previous social relationships and histories of economic migration. 

China Sajadian, an Anthropology PhD candidate at the City University of New York Graduate Center, undertook eighteen months of research in Lebanon because Lebanon hosts the highest number of refugees per capita in the world. Over one-quarter of Lebanon's population is composed of displaced Syrians, the majority of whom are displaced former labor migrants, which made the effects of forced migration there appropriately visible for targeted data collection and analysis. Sajadian collected data with two primary methods. To document everyday labor practices and the specific effects of refugee settlement, she conducted ethnographic research, including observation and interviews, among a stratified sample of 250 farmworkers in villages adjacent to the Syrian-Lebanese border in the Bekaa Valley of Lebanon. This included observing social ties between Syrian labor migrants who worked in Lebanon before the crisis, landlords, labor overseers, and refugees, particularly the processes through which rents and wages are paid and the internal political economy of Syrian farmworker-refugee camps. She also pursued archival research about the history of land tenure, labor, and migration in the region. 

The researcher discovered that Syrian farmworkers' loss of cross-border mobility throughout the Syrian war is the key factor in explaining shifts in agricultural conditions of this region. Syrian farmworkers, who constitute the vast majority of Lebanon's low-paid agricultural labor force, used to migrate to Lebanon during the spring and summer and return to Syria in the winter, where they received health care and schooling for their children. Since the war in Syria began, most farmworkers are unable to return to Syria in the winter and must now cope with the higher cost of living in Lebanon year-round. Facing the loss of social services from the Syrian state and an independent source of seasonal subsistence from their land in Syria, displaced Syrian farmworkers have become increasingly dependent on hierarchical bonded labor arrangements in Lebanon. This is most evident in the shift from pre-war temporary labor camps (warshat) to semi-permanent refugee camps (mukhayamat). Though labor camps have existed in the Bekaa Valley for many decades, the network of camps expanded significantly after Syrians began to flee to Lebanon en masse with the start of the 2011 Syrian conflict. These camps are overseen by headmen (shaweesh), well-established Syrian former labor migrants with access to social connections and economic resources who lend services, temporary housing, and work opportunities on credit to destitute refugee families in need of a reliable source of income and shelter. In most cases, these camps are not new, but rather an expansion of pre-existing labor camps, hosting a mix of newcomers and previous labor migrants. The researcher found that the camp headmen, despite being exploiters of refugee labor,  successfully maintain their authority through paternalistic relations with the camp residents, who critically depend upon the headmen's function as providers of essential services, without which they could not survive the high cost of living in Lebanon.

These findings suggest that, in order to understand the social effects of forced migration, scholars and policymakers should take into account the long-term histories of migration in the regions in which refugees settle. Findings from this research will inform policy makers about how loss of cross-border mobility for seasonal farmworkers reconfigures social and economic relations in the country of settlement. Knowledge of these processes will help policy makers develop approaches for dealing with refugees that are attentive to the specific predicaments, livelihood needs, and security challenges of borderland regions. Findings from the research also will be disseminated through academic publications and conference presentations.
